About Board Minutes Achievements Events

A better Millbrook starts with all of us

The Millbrook Betterment Committee is a nonpartisan, volunteer-run civic organization dedicated to improving our community. Founded in 2021, our seven board members bring diverse perspectives united by a single vision: Millbrook deserves better.

"We believe that Millbrook's best days are ahead of it. Through thoughtful action, community engagement, and a shared commitment to progress, we will transform Millbrook into the place we all know it can be."
— ADOPTED UNANIMOUSLY AT THE FIRST MEETING, MARCH 2021 (AFTER 90 MINUTES OF DEBATE OVER THE WORD "TRANSFORM")

Your Board

Carol Pemberton

CHAIR · JOINED 2021

Carol has lived in Millbrook for 38 years and has strong opinions about traffic flow. She drives a 2018 Chevy Tahoe and believes the downtown area could use "at least two hundred more spots, maybe three hundred."

"Progress means never having to circle the block."

Tom Huang

VICE-CHAIR · JOINED 2021

Tom spent a semester in Amsterdam in 2003 and has thought about it every single day since. He bikes to every meeting. He has given fourteen presentations on protected bike lanes. Carol has attended all fourteen.

"Imagine if Main Street had no cars. Just imagine it."

Debra Fontaine

TREASURER · JOINED 2021

Debra runs a home candle business called "Deb's Delights" and is passionate about supporting local artisans. She has proposed a farmers market at every meeting since the committee's founding. The committee's operating budget is $340. Debra manages it personally.

"A community without a market isn't really a community."

Raj Iyer

SECRETARY · JOINED 2021

Raj is a night-shift ER nurse at Millbrook General. He takes meticulous meeting notes and has never once attended a committee social event, which take place in the evening, when he is sleeping. His sole legislative interest is noise.

"I just think we could all be a little quieter."

Nina Kowalski

EVENTS COORDINATOR · JOINED 2022

Nina has four dogs (Biscuit, Pretzel, Noodle, and Frank) and is a tireless advocate for public green space. Every proposal Nina makes includes an off-leash component. She does not notice this pattern. Nobody has pointed it out.

"Green space is the heartbeat of any town. Also, where do people exercise their dogs currently? A parking lot? That's inhumane."

Frank Bellini

MEMBER-AT-LARGE · JOINED 2021

Frank is a retired postal worker and lifelong Millbrook resident. He believes the town began to decline in 2017 when Margherita's Pizzeria opened on Elm Street. He has not explained this connection to anyone's satisfaction. He brings it up at every meeting.

"All I'm saying is, before Margherita's, we didn't have these problems."

Owen Park

MEMBER · JOINED 2024

Owen is 22, recently graduated from SUNY Purchase, and joined the committee because his mother told him to "get involved in something." He is not sure what the committee does. He is very positive about it. He has volunteered for every subcommittee and completed nothing.

"I think what we're doing here is really important. Like, genuinely."

Recent Meeting Minutes

FEBRUARY 8, 2025 — MILLBROOK PUBLIC LIBRARY, ROOM B

7:02 PM
Carol calls meeting to order. Notes that she had to park on Birch Street because the library lot was full. "This is exactly what I'm talking about." Tom suggests that if fewer people drove, the lot wouldn't be full. Carol tables the discussion.
7:08 PM
Debra presents updated farmers market proposal (v.14). Includes a map, vendor applications, and a suggested candle booth in the center ("for ambiance"). Frank asks if Margherita's would be allowed a booth. Debra says all local businesses are welcome. Frank says "then what's the point."
7:19 PM
Nina proposes that any new public space include a water fountain "for residents and their companions." Raj asks if the fountain could be a quiet model. Nina says she'll look into it. Tom says the space should be car-free. Carol says "let's not get ahead of ourselves."
7:31 PM
Frank asks the board to consider the "Margherita's question." He presents a chart showing correlation between the restaurant's opening and a rise in "general dissatisfaction." Owen asks what data the chart is based on. Frank says "the feeling around town." Owen says "okay cool."
7:44 PM
Tom presents a 22-slide deck titled "Millbrook 2030: A Bikeable Future." Slide 7 includes a rendering of Main Street with no cars. Carol asks him to skip to the summary. Tom says every slide is the summary. Carol lets him continue. Raj notes that bicycles are "essentially silent" and expresses rare enthusiasm.
8:03 PM
Motion proposed: "The committee commits to pursuing improvements to Millbrook's public spaces in a manner consistent with the community's values." Passes 7-0. Specific improvements not defined. Carol calls it "real progress." Owen claps.
8:06 PM
Raj moves to adjourn. Seconded by everyone immediately.

Our Achievements

2022

Successfully Petitioned to Extend Library Hours

After a six-month campaign, the library now closes at 8 PM instead of 7 PM on Thursdays. Carol was in favor (more time to park). Tom was in favor (evening bike access). Raj was against (noise). Raj was outvoted but appreciated that the meeting about it ended early.

2023

Community Cleanup Day

27 volunteers picked up litter along Elm Street and Maple Avenue. Nina brought all four dogs. Pretzel ate a glove. Frank spent the entire event standing outside Margherita's, picking up litter "within a very specific radius." Owen showed up two hours late but stayed an extra hour to compensate. Debra handed out candle samples. Three volunteers later reported headaches.

2023

Town Hall Presentation

The committee presented a unified vision for Millbrook's future to the Town Council. The presentation included Carol's parking study, Tom's bike lane renderings, Debra's market plans, Nina's green space proposal, and Frank's Margherita's chart. The Council thanked the committee and said they would "take it under advisement." Nothing has been advised since. The committee considers this a win.

2024

Installed a Bench

After eighteen months of deliberation, the committee installed a bench on the corner of Main and Oak. The bench faces east. Carol wanted it facing the parking lot. Tom wanted it facing the (hypothetical) bike lane. Nina wanted it near the grass. Frank wanted it facing away from Margherita's. The final orientation was a compromise that faces a brick wall. Raj said he appreciates that the bench "doesn't make any noise." Owen painted it. He chose teal. Nobody asked for teal.

From the Newsletter

Chair's Corner — February 2025

Dear neighbors,

As we enter our fourth year, I am proud to say the Millbrook Betterment Committee is stronger than ever. Our board represents the full spectrum of what makes Millbrook great — passion, dedication, and a willingness to show up on the second Thursday of every month, even when the library's parking lot is, once again, completely full.

This month we passed an important resolution affirming our commitment to improvement. While the specifics are still being discussed, the spirit of the resolution is clear: Millbrook can do better. We all agree on this. We have always agreed on this. What "better" means is, of course, something we will continue to explore together, as a committee, in the months and years ahead.

On a personal note, I want to acknowledge Frank, who has shown incredible dedication to his ongoing research into what he calls "the Elm Street question." While the board has not formally adopted his findings, we respect his commitment to the investigative process.

See you on the 14th. Please carpool if possible. Not because of the environment — because of the parking.

— Carol Pemberton, Chair
"Betterment begins with showing up. And finding a spot."

Upcoming Events

MAR 14

Monthly Board Meeting

Millbrook Public Library, Room B. Agenda items include: Debra's farmers market proposal (v.15), Tom's revised bike lane presentation (now 31 slides), and continued discussion of the bench. Nina will bring Biscuit. Raj has pre-filed a noise concern.

APR 5

Spring Community Walk

A guided walk through downtown Millbrook to "identify areas for improvement." Route planned by Tom (avoids all roads). Alternate route planned by Carol (avoids all hills). Nina has requested that dogs be permitted. Frank has requested that the walk not pass Margherita's. Both requests have been accommodated, leaving a route that is approximately one block long.

MAY 10

Second Annual Millbrook Betterment Picnic

Location TBD. Last year's picnic was held in the library parking lot after the park was rejected (Nina: "not enough shade for the dogs"), the town square was rejected (Frank: "too close to Margherita's"), and the school field was rejected (Raj: "the church bells"). Owen has volunteered to DJ. He has not been asked to DJ. He has purchased speakers.
